entries.author: paul_johnson
entries.text: The Perl Foundation was accepted to participate in the Google Code-in. Now it is time to find students between the ages 13-17 years who are interested to participate. That's where The Perl Foundation needs your help. See the post of  Paul Johnson (pjcj) with details.
entries.title: Perl Accepted For GCI - Now We Just Need Students

entries.author: peteris_krumins
entries.text: Peteris Krumins continues his series about Perl one-liners. This time looking at regular expressions. Some of them are useful, for others there are CPAN modules that serve the purpose better than a regex.
entries.title: Famous Perl One-Liners Explained, Part VII: Handy Regular Expressions

entries.text: David Precious (bigpersh) wanted to produce some graphs for a Dancer based application. After looking around on CPAN he settled with Chart::Strip. There is a small example code and the resulting graph in the blog.
entries.title: Graphing time-based data in Perl

entries.author: sebastian_willing
entries.text: Sebastian Willing show how to use Memcached to keep already computed data in memory in a way that survives even a restart to the web-server.
entries.title: Intelligent caching for all time statistics

entries.text: John Wang takes some ideas from Ruby and shows how to implement 'confident code' in Moose. It's up for discussion to figure out if this is a good or a bad way to show the power of Moose.
entries.title: Confident Code Using Systematic, Automated Input Validation

entries.text: When you copy-paste some code, do you create 'technical debt', 'friction' or are you driving up the premium you pay for your 'technical insurance'? It's only a question of metaphor but explaining the problem in a way that is easier to understand for business people is important. Hence the article of  Jeff Thalhammer on the Moder Perl Books web site.
entries.title: Technical Quality is an Insurance Policy

entries.author: jeffrey_kegler
entries.text: Jeffrey Kegler pitches his Marpa engine against the regex engine of Perl. He says that in some cases Marpa is much faster than any regex could be. Then a discussion with Tom Christiansen makes the whole article even more interesting.
entries.title: Marpa v. Perl regexes: some numbers

entries.text: Ian Norton (idn) has published his slides from the 'Learning Perl Together' workshop he gave at the London Perl Workshop
entries.title: London Perl Workshop - Learning Perl Together

entries.author: dave_cross
entries.text: Dave Cross gave a very good 90 minute long talk about what is new in Perl 5.10, 5.12, 5.14 and even in the not-yet-released 5.16. He is sharing his slides here.
entries.title: Modern Core Perl Slides

entries.author: dave_jacoby
entries.text: Dave Jacoby shows an example how NYTProf lead him to caching result pages reducing the response time by more than 50%. It was interesting to see now as I am planning to do the same with my simple blog engine.
entries.title: Caching pages - Beyond Firebug to NYTProf

entries.author: gabor_szabo
entries.title: Perl Tutorial: Scalar and List context in Perl, the size of an array

entries.author: jonathan_worthington
entries.title: Slides from the Optimizing Rakudo Perl 6 talk

entries.text: A couple of days ago Yitzchak Scott-Thoennes mentioned to me that the 'Fun with Perl' mailing list suddenly woke up. Judging from the archive it isn't a busy list but a very rewarding one. Assuming you like that kind of fun.
entries.title: Fun with Perl

entries.author: brian_d_foy
entries.text: brian d foy describes his experience at a conference where most of the talks are in a language he does not understand and also finds time to introduce Data::Printer. Nice pictures too.
entries.title: What I learned from YAPC::Brasil

entries.text: David Precious (bigpersh) reports about the London Perl Workshop.
entries.title: LPW2011 : my thoughts overall

entries.author: dave_cross
entries.text: Dave Cross is running an 'Intermediate Perl' and an 'Advanced Perl' course in February 2012 in central London.
entries.title: Public Perl training in London

header: I am sending this from London where I attended the UK Perl Workshop. It was great. There were lots of interesting talks that I missed because I was giving a 4 hour training.
There was also a social event after, that I enjoyed very much. There were some 220-250 people who came to the event.
GCI - TPF needs your help to locate teenagers who would like to participate in the Google Code-in and do Perl related projects.
subject: London Perl Workshop and the Modern Core Perl Slides
